Yes, there are several endangered species that are found in the forests of Cordillera. These include:

1. Philippine eagle (Pithecophaga jefferyi) - The Philippine eagle is one of the most critically endangered raptors in the world, with an estimated population of fewer than 500 individuals. It can be found in the Cordillera forests and is protected through conservation efforts such as habitat protection and breeding programs.

2. Philippine tarsier (Tarsius syrichta) - The Philippine tarsier is a small primate that is native to the Philippines, including the forests of Cordillera. It is an endangered species due to habitat loss and hunting, and is protected through conservation efforts such as habitat protection and awareness-raising campaigns.

3. Cloud rat (Phloeomys pallidus and Crateromys schadenbergi) - The cloud rat is a nocturnal animal that can only be found in the high-altitude forests of Cordillera. It is an endangered species due to habitat loss and hunting for its meat and fur. Conservation efforts include the establishment of protected areas and the promotion of sustainable hunting practices among local communities.

4. Philippine cockatoo (Cacatua haematuropygia) - The Philippine cockatoo is a critically endangered bird that can be found in the Cordillera forests. It is threatened by habitat loss, hunting, and capture for the pet trade. The species is protected through conservation efforts such as habitat protection, breeding programs, and education and awareness-raising campaigns.

In general, species protection in the Cordillera forests involves a combination of legal protection, habitat conservation, and community-based management. Protected areas that support the conservation of these species are established and maintained by the government and non-governmental organizations. Additionally, community-based conservation efforts, such as sustainable forest management practices and education and awareness-raising campaigns, involve the participation of local communities in the conservation of endangered species.
